title: Garth Hill / Mountain Walk Route

images.title: Gareth James / View NE from Garth Hill
images.caption: View NE from Garth Hill. A view from the eastern end of the hill, overlooking Taff's Well and the River Taff.

images.title: eswales / Woodland, Garth Hill
images.caption: View of woodland on the slopes of Garth Hill from an elevated position on the opposite (eastern) side of Cwm Du.

images.title: Steve Sheppard / Trig point on Tumulus on Garth Hill
images.caption: A walker stands on the trig point atop the hill.

images.title: Gareth Evans / Taff Gorge from sandstone crag on Garth Hill
images.caption: A view of the Taff Gorge from a sandstone crag on Garth Hill. Upper Carboniferous rocks underlie the foreground and have been mined historically for coal. The conspicuous settlement, Taff's Well, lies on alluvium and river terraces of the Taff. The wooded ridges either side of the gorge are of lower Carboniferous limestones which are currently quarried and have been mined historically for iron.

images.title: Alan Hughes / Garth hill
images.caption: View across the Taff Vale towards the Garth on a crystal clear December day. Until the 19th century, the valley and the lower slopes of the Garth facing Taff's Well were full of small coal mines which fed the ironworks. Little trace remains today.

images.title: Alan Hughes / Taffs Well
images.caption: View southeast from The Garth over Taffs Well. Somerset visible beyond the Bristol Channel.

images.title: Dominic Nelson, CC BY-SA 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gwaelod y Garth Inn. Head here for some refreshments after your climb.

images.title: View downstream from the footbridge at Gwaelod-y-garth by John Lord, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View downstream from the footbridge at Gwaelod-y-garth. There are nice views of the River Taff in this area.

description: This challenging walk takes you to the summit of Garth Hill or Mountain near Cardiff. The hill is thought to be the inspiration for the fictional hill featured in the film 'The Englishman Who Went Up a Hill But Came Down a Mountain' starring Hugh Grant. The walk begins in the village of Taff's Well and follows the Taff Ely Ridgeway Walk to the 307 m (1,007 ft) summit. Here you can enjoy fantastic views of Cardiff, the Bristol Channel and the Taff Valley. You will also find a number of burial sites dating from the early to middle Bronze Age, around 2000 BC. You descend on country lanes, crossing the River Taff and finishing back in Taff's Well. To extend your walking in the area just head a mile to the east and visit Castle Coch and Fforest Fawr .
county: Rhondda Cynon Taf - Rhondda Cynon Taf
